Seeking asylum is not a crime. We're suing.
 ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌

Dear ##SM_RULE_360 Email Salutation##,

All across the deep south, the Trump administration is undertaking a massive and secretive expansion of its mass detention state.

Asylum-seekers fleeing violence and persecution are being warehoused in brutal conditions and systematically denied parole.

We're fighting back against this effort to criminalize asylum — and last week, together with our partners at SPLC, we scored a decisive victory.

A federal court granted our request and ordered the Trump administration to immediately restore the right to parole to asylum-seekers who have been so inhumanely and brutally imprisoned.

Read more about the case and our fight to stop Trump's mass detention and deportation agenda.

This is a big win, but our fight isn't over yet.

There are still thousands of immigrants and asylum-seekers languishing in jails and private prisons across Louisiana. Even U.S. citizens, like our client Ramon Torres, are not immune to being racially-profiled and detained.

This hateful anti-immigrant agenda is unfair, unjust and deeply un-American — and we're not backing down from our fight against it.

Thanks for standing with us,

Alanah Odoms Hebert
Executive Director, ACLU of Louisiana
